title: AAQ: Why Does Krishna Let Us Suffer? | His Grace Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa
speaker: HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa

segments.key_quote: So, if God is all merciful, why doesn't he protect his devotees all the time?
segments.summary: The lecture begins by posing the question of why Krishna allows suffering, especially among devotees, despite being merciful.

segments.key_quote: To the extent we surrender unto Krishna, to that extent, Krishna will protect us.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Krishna's protection is proportional to one's surrender and faith, using Arjuna's unwavering conviction as an example.

segments.key_quote: Prahlad Maharaj was fully convinced Krishna is my sole protector.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of Prahlad Maharaj's unwavering faith and the story of John F. Kennedy's inability to save his child to illustrate that material means are insufficient without Krishna's sanction.

segments.key_quote: Behind all this, unless Krishna sanctions, the parents' protection for the child will not work.
segments.summary: The speaker provides further analogies of a CEO unable to save his father despite the best medicine and the Titanic's sinking to emphasize that Krishna's sanction is ultimately necessary for protection and success.

segments.key_quote: To the extent we are surrendered to Krishna, to that extent Krishna will protect.
segments.summary: The speaker recounts Prahlad Maharaj drinking poison unharmed due to his complete surrender and devotion, emphasizing that Krishna responds to devotion and surrender, like a father favoring an obedient child.

segments.key_quote: Ultimately Krishna's protection is for the soul, not for the body.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that while devotees still face physical challenges, Krishna's ultimate protection is the liberation of the soul from repeated birth and death, offering a return to Godhead.

segments.key_quote: Krishna says, I am equal to everyone. I am impartial.
segments.summary: The speaker addresses the apparent contradiction of Krishna being impartial yet favoring devotees, explaining that Krishna's impartiality lies in granting free will while constantly striving to bring souls back to Him through scriptures, devotees, and incarnations.

segments.key_quote: Any living entity comes to me and surrenders unto me saying, Tavasmi, O Ramachandra, I am yours. Please accept me. Abhayam Sarvada Dasyami. I will eternally protect him.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of Vibhishana surrendering to Ramachandra to illustrate Krishna's promise to protect anyone who surrenders, regardless of their past, while those who don't surrender are governed by the law of karma.

segments.key_quote: The moment we fully surrender to Krishna, no matter how much sinful activities we have accumulated in our past lives, Krishna says, all of that finished.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating that suffering arises from the law of karma for those not fully surrendered, but complete surrender to Krishna nullifies past sins and guarantees protection and liberation, emphasizing Krishna's mercy and impartiality.
